Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will support five principal investigators, Kaustubh Agashe, Zackaria Chacko, S. James Gates Jr., Rabindra N. Mohapatra and Raman Sundrum, to continue their on-going theoretical investigations into the nature and origin of the constituents of matter and the forces operating between them as well as the possible existence of extra hidden space dimensions. The PIs will use existing mathematical tools developed for this purpose and seek new ones. They plan to study the nature of the Higgs boson, a major discovery of the past year in the field, the particle that gives mass to matter, and the possible existence of its companion particles that may be indicating any new symmetries or possibly giving mass to tiny particles filling the universe called the neutrinos. This is expected not only to broaden our understanding of the known subatomic phenomena but also in the process, discover new ones that can be tested in machines such as the Large Hadron Collider. The ultimate goal of this research is to seek a fundamental unity among the forces and matter and their impact on the evolution of the Cosmos. These investigations will throw light on such questions as the origin of matter and dark matter in the universe as well as the origin of dark energy and dark radiation.

The combination of big picture excitement,intellectual challenge and connections to diverse experiments makes this project an excellent training ground. The project is therefore weighted towards supporting two students and two postdocs. There is a substantial component of education and outreach to broaden the impact of the research, including research for undergraduate and high school students, with an emphasis on students from historically black colleges. The work in this project will be disseminated even more broadly through public and school lectures, and media broadcasts and interviews.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF award was made to five principal investigators Kaustubh Agashe, Zacharia Chacko, S. James Gates Jr., Rabindra N. Mohapatra and Raman Sundrum. The main focus of this project was to conduct theoretical investigations of fundamental physics at the subnuclear level with the goal of expanding our knowledge of the forces and constituents of nature and understanding of the Cosmos in a way that could be tested in current particle physics and cosmology experiments. Topics in particle physics studied covered a broad range of topics such as Higgs physics, supersymmetry, extra space dimensions, neutrino physics and grand unification of matter and forces. Topics in cosmology covered the nature and origin of matter, dark matter and dark energy and their implications for the large scale structure of the universe. A major unifying theme was the search for new physics relevant to the above topics that could be testable at the CERN Large Hadron Collider and various ongoing non-accelerator searches.  Our results are a combination of discovering new theoretical mechanisms at the juncture of Quantum Mechanics and Relativity and developing experimental strategies for testing them.

Major outcomes: In the domain of neutrino physics, we explored how observations can be understood using extensions of the standard model such as the left-right symmetric models and grand unified theories of forces. Specifically it was shown how these ideas to understand the neutrinos and the origin of matter in the universe can be tested at the Large Hadron Collider and in the planned searches for matter stability. In the area of dark matter, mechanisms were constructed to understand observed astrophysical anomalies with respect to the standard "cold dark matter" paradigm, and the sensitivity of new experiments to them was explored. In cosmology, a new class of high-scale inflationary multi-axion models was developed for the "growth spurt" of the early universe, along with their possibly observable signatures in the cosmic microwave background.   Within collider physics, new techniques were developed to help determine the parameters of the underlying physics models, including those giving dark matter. The motivation and study of displaced vertex decays as a spectacular signature of long-lived new particles was undertaken and new experimental strategies identified. New, natural, extensions of the Composite Higgs mechanism were developed, consistent with earlier data, and shown to give a rich resonance phenomenology for the Large Hadron Collider. The work of SJG has resulted in finding new connections of supersymmetry to information theory, graph theory, and algebraic geometry.

Broader impact and outreach: The NSF-supported PIs at Maryland had a substantial role in training graduate students and post-doctoral researchers. During the past three years, nine graduate students were supervised in our group and we trained four post-docs (supported by a combination of NSF and university funds). We also mentored several undergraduate students. Our research results were disseminated via publications in peer reviewed journals as well as through presentations in international conferences, and have spurred further research in the field. Several outreach measures to the general public were undertaken, including consulting for the scientific media, delivering public and high school lectures, and appearing on TV science specials. This plays an essential role in bringing the excitement of fundamental physics to the public and in inspiring scientific curiosity in the next generation.
